title: 110_s1672
content: The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes the Visual Impairment and Orientation and Mobility Professionals Education Assistance Program under Chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code. The VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 establishes a scholarship program to provide financial assistance for individuals studying visual impairment or orientation and mobility. The scholarship program established under the VA Vision Scholars Act of 2007 aims to increase the number of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation by providing financial assistance to students pursuing degrees or certificates in visual impairment or orientation and mobility at accredited educational institutions. Students must enter into an agreement with the Secretary to be eligible for the scholarship. The Secretary is responsible for publicizing the scholarship program. The scholarship program aims to increase the supply of qualified blind rehabilitation specialists for the Department and the Nation. The Secretary is responsible for publicizing the program to educational institutions, with a focus on those with high numbers of Hispanic students and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. To participate, individuals must submit an application and agreement to the Secretary. To participate in the scholarship program, individuals must submit an application and agreement to the Secretary, agreeing to serve a period of obligated service in return for educational assistance. The Secretary will provide application and agreement forms with a fair summary of rights and liabilities to interested individuals. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals are notified in writing and become participants in the scholarship program. The Secretary provides a fair summary of rights and liabilities, as well as a full description of terms and conditions for participation. Upon approval by the Secretary, individuals are notified in writing and become participants in the scholarship program. The amount of financial assistance provided covers tuition and fees for the individual's program of study. The financial assistance provided under this chapter covers tuition and fees for the program of study, with a maximum amount set for each academic year. The financial assistance provided under this chapter has a maximum amount of $15,000 for full-time students and $45,000 overall. Part-time students receive assistance based on the ratio of their coursework to full-time coursework. The maximum amount of financial assistance provided under this chapter is $45,000, with a maximum duration of six years. An agreement between the Secretary and a participant in the scholarship program must be in writing and signed by the participant, outlining the financial assistance provided. The participant must agree to accept financial assistance, maintain enrollment and attendance in the program of study, and maintain an acceptable academic standing while enrolled. The participant must agree to accept financial assistance, maintain enrollment, and academic standing in the program. They are required to serve as a full-time employee in the Department for three years after completing the program. The Secretary may determine other terms and conditions for this agreement. Repayment is required if the participant fails to meet the agreement requirements. An individual receiving educational assistance must repay the unearned portion if they fail to meet the agreement requirements, as determined by the Secretary. Repayment amount and exceptions are regulated by the Secretary. The Secretary regulates repayment procedures and exceptions for individuals receiving educational assistance. Waiver or suspension of obligations may be granted in certain circumstances, and noncompliance may result in an obligation to repay. The Secretary may waive or suspend compliance obligations if it benefits the United States. Repayment to the Secretary is considered a debt to the United States, not discharged by bankruptcy within five years of agreement termination. Clerical amendments are made to title 38. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement chapter 80 of title 38, United States Code within six months of this Act's enactment.
